title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in Section 2. It is illegal to import, export, or transport fur or steel-jawed leghold traps across state lines. Additionally, selling or purchasing traps that violate these regulations is prohibited. Violation of regulations regarding the import, export, or transportation of steel-jawed leghold traps may result in imprisonment or fines under title 18, United States Code. Subsequent violations carry harsher penalties. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees of the government are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import violations are treated as customs law violations. Enforcement authorities under the Export Administration Act of 1979 are used to enforce violations related to exports. Any person with enforcement authority may detain, search, and seize packages for inspection. Enforcement authorities under the Export Administration Act of 1979 have the authority to detain, search, and seize packages for inspection if there is reasonable cause to suspect a violation of the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages for inspection if there is reasonable cause to suspect a violation of the Export Administration Act of 1979. They have the power to make warrantless arrests for violations of the Act and execute warrants issued by judges or magistrates for enforcement purposes. (d) Forfeiture.-- Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap can be forfeited for violations of this Act, except for exports covered by the Export Administration Act of 1979 and imports under US customs laws. Any fur article or steel-jawed leghold trap found in violation of this Act or related rules may be forfeited to the United States, subject to seizure and judicial procedures outlined in customs laws. The procedures for seizures and forfeitures under this Act, including the sale, remission, mitigation, and compromise of claims, apply to property seized under this subsection. The Secretary can enforce these duties similar to customs laws in the United States. States may conduct seizures and forfeitures of property under this Act, authorized by the Secretary or designated officers. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators, and cooperation is required from various government departments and agencies. The Secretary of Commerce, Treasury, and other relevant agencies must cooperate to enforce this Act and its rules effectively. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" includes any furskin or article made in whole or part of furskin. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" refers to a device with two opposing steel jaws activated by a spring or sear. The term "import" means to bring into the United States jurisdiction. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may create rules to implement the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
